title: Netflix stock falls again as the previous most-bullish analyst slashes price target
text:
Shares of Netflix Inc. sank again Tuesday, enough to turn negative for this year, after the previously most-bullish analyst slashed his price target to below the Wall Street average, citing expectations that the path to profitability will take longer than expected.

The streaming-video giant’s stock NFLX, -4.26% dropped 4.8% in afternoon trading, putting it on track for the lowest close since Dec. 26. The stock has now tumbled 15% amid a 5-session losing streak, and has lost one-third of its value since the July 3 closing high of $381.72.

In the process, the price has fallen below a 3-year long uptrend line, and is on the verge of creating another bearish long-term technical pattern. (See charts below)

Analyst Jeff Wlodarczak at Pivotal Research affirmed the buy rating he’s had on Netflix for at least the past three years, but lowered his price target by 32% to $350. His target was still 38% above current levels, but was now 11% below the average price target of $393.26, of the 40 analysts surveyed by FactSet.

Wlodarczak’s previous price target of $515 was the highest of those surveyed by a wide margin, as the current highest target is now Imperial Capital analyst David Miller’s target of $451, according to FactSet data.

The lowered target reflects “materially higher than forecast content cost inflation,” Wlodarczak wrote in a note to clients. He said the higher cost outlook is highlighted by what AT&T Inc. T, -0.59% paid for the exclusive streaming rights to carry the “The Big Bang Theory” TV show. In addition, he noted that the big internet players appear to be significantly ramping their advertising spend, which was highlighted by ads showing during the Emmy awards show over the weekend.

See related: ‘Seinfeld’ is coming to Netflix — all 180 episodes of it.

Also read: Everything coming to Netflix in September — and what’s leaving.

“Against this backdrop of accelerating industry spend we believe the right move for [Netflix] management is to also materially accelerate their spend,” Wlodarczak wrote, which he believes is needed to maintain its “sizeable content lead” on its peers, increase barriers to entry, reduce churn and maintain growth in subscribers and average revenue per user (ARPU). He said, however, that increased spending could temporary pressure margins and free cash flow.

Netflix had reported in July second-quarter free cash flow of negative $593.8 million, up from negative $558.6 million in the same period a year ago. In its annual report out in January, Netflix reported 2018 free cash flow of negative $3.02 billion, compared with negative $2.02 billion in 2017, and said it expected negative free cash flow “for many years” as it continues to “significantly increase” investment in streaming content.

Don’t miss: Opinion: Netflix stock is a buy right now — for these 10 reasons.

Also read: Netflix snags ‘Game of Thrones’ creators away from HBO in mega-deal.

Wlodarczak kept his subscriber estimates mostly intact but raised his medium-term cost forecasts, as his assumption for annual cash outlay on programming was lifted to $35 billion in 2025 from $30 billion.

He also cut his 2019 earnings-per-share estimate to $3.64 from $3.93 and lowered his sales outlook to $20.18 billion from $20.20 billion.

“Our new forecasts imply [Netflix is] going to respond to content cost acceleration by revving up their own content spend that will allow them to maintain their subscriber growth while pushing back profitability materially,” Wlodarczak wrote.

In the end, his view is that very few players will be able to keep up current spend levels, and that ultimately it will be a “2-horse race,” Netflix and Walt Disney Co.’s Disney+, where both horses can win. Wlodarczak said he believes Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -2.45% will be on the periphery, and there is a reasonable shot that AT&T will screw up HBO as a competitor.”

Don’t miss: ‘Disney will win’ streaming battle with Netflix: analyst.

Netflix’s stock has shed 31% over the past 12 months, while Disney shares DIS, -0.37% have climbed 17%, AT&T shares have gained 11% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.53% has edged up 1%.

Trendline break ends 3-year uptrend

Netflix’s stock has fallen below a trendline on the weekly charts, that has defined the trajectory of the current uptrend going back to September 2016.

FactSet, MarketWatch

One of the six key tenets of the Dow Theory, which has remained relevant among technical analysts for over a century, is that a trend remains in effect until it gives a definite signal that it has reversed, according to the CMT Association. One of the simplest and widely used tools by chart watchers, to gauge when a trend has ended is a trendline.

While the trendline break warns that Netflix’s long-term stock uptrend appears to have ended, some chart watchers require a sign that a new downtrend has begun before turning fully bearish.

Another key Dow Theory tenet is that a downtrend is defined by a pattern of lower highs and lower lows.

FactSet, MarketWatch

Netflix’s stock has already made a lower high, as the May 3 close of $385.03, the highest close of 2019, was well below the July 19, 2018 record close of $418.97. If the stock closes below the Dec. 24, 2018 close of $233.88, which at the time was an 11-month low, the lower low would complete the Dow Theory’s definition of a downtrend.

The stock would have to decline another 7.7% from current levels to complete the pattern.
description: Shares of Netflix Inc. sank again Tuesday, enough to turn negative for this year, after the previously most-bullish analyst slashed his price target to below...
